Posts.Content: diana50 wrote: hi everyone* hope you are all doing well; hanging in there and enjoying every day and your peeps...and animals...kids....cycling...running..cooking...photography....etc..¬† also Happy Thanksgiving; it is just around the corner.¬† i also hope those of you out east are doing ok.... well, today was my last radiation to my spine.¬† cancer was in T4 and rad onc radiated T3 and T5 and of course T4. the T3 and T5 was to create margins (like they do in surgery) around the cancer.¬† the tumor in T4 was very large.¬† i saw it; i was shocked.¬† still no pain at all in the vertebra with the cancer.¬† oh wait; the cancer is NOW gone.¬† 25 rads kicked it to the curb. so now, i take femara daily and zometa monthly for 2 years.¬† so far so good.¬† i will have a PET scan end of dec or early jan.¬† apparently, you want to wait 6 weeks after last rads before PET scan.¬† that is what i doc said anyway.¬† my oncologist is optimistic and so am i.¬† she said she has many patients with stage iv disease doing well 10 YEARS or more out.¬† my progression was exactly like my cancer in 2002; it hadn't changed at all which means i wasn't cured....but had great response to treatment.¬† maybe i should have stayed on AI.¬† i don't know. at the time i was done.¬† you do what you do....and deal with what comes down the pike.¬† at any rate; hang in there. i found my journal from a few years out from diagnosis...2003 2004..and i was really struggling with fears...etc.¬† it was good to read my fears from the past...and see how things changed in almost 11 years later.¬† my biggest fear was relapse to stage iv and now here it is...and i really just see this as more stuff to do to fight cancer.¬† just living my life pretty much like i was before the spine met showed up.¬† you all take good care. keep on...keeping on* diana Not today cancer. Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2009 09:25AM diana50 wrote: Hi If your doctor orders an MRI you can assume that they believe you need to have one and it is medically necessary.¬† My oncologist usually has to talk to the physcian from the insurance company who regulates these scans. Previous scans, or mammos are often included because often times the radiaologsit will recommend futher testing; ie, MRI, ultrasound, etc.¬† I believe that in the recent years the insurance companies have become really tough on scans...but of recent breast MRI's are pretty much standard care; especially for women who have dense breasts.¬† It is becoming standard for your personal doctors to talk to the insurance companies.¬† Sad, but true. Always fight for what you need.¬† Call your insurance company if you need to.

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2009 03:22PM diana50 wrote: i would talk with my oncologist and describe the symptoms.¬† taxotere and taxel can give you nerve pain down to your feet and hands.¬† burning tingling sensations.¬† there are medicines you can take that help with that specifically, cymbalta is an antidepressant which has a property in it that decrease nerve pain.¬† i take it and have found it helpful.¬† i am on a low dose..and it seems to help. neurontin is another med specially for nerve pain...foot. and hand.¬† my experience so far (7 years later) that my body still aches on some level.¬† arimidex really knocked my socks off...and now i am off it and feeling better.¬† of course i am now 57 and not the young woman i was at 49 when diagnosed¬† i am a cyclist; i ride 100+ miles a week.¬† when i am cycling no big problems. guess cycling keeps the joiunts oiled...but other times stiff and achey.¬† i think a lot of this depends on what chemo you got; rads or not...and what hormine drug you are on if you are on one. i don't like the aches and pains...but i can live with it.¬† i don't regret the aggressive treatment i got.¬† but, it is hard to have your body change so much.¬† but, as i said; i am an older woman now. lol¬† hahaha hang in best wishes diana50

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 09:37AM diana50 wrote: I remember having aches and pains after chemo...rads...i also had neuropathy from taxotere. it takes a while for your body to begin to feel better.¬† i went from chemo...rads...arimidex in a span of 5-6 months.¬† one right after the other and i am sure most of us do.¬† the toxins in your body are still creating havoc...i was talking to my cardiologist a little while ago and he told me very clearly that chemo and rads (not ignoring arimidex) is poisen and designed to kill cancer...along with others cells.¬† give yourself some time...your system is still really vunerable to things it wasn't before treatment.¬† these are some things to try:¬† 1. BEFORE you get out of bed; stretch your body...including joints. especially ankles.¬† arms above head and stretch...sit on the bed...and stretch again..and then get up. 2) cold packs helps inflamation.¬† i experienced a lot of inflamation after all the treatments.¬† i also used cold packs under my arm and chest/boob when i am achey. it seems to help. 3) walking in the evenings or morning is good. 4) if you work out...pace yourself.¬† give yourself a year or more to really begin to heal.¬† i did have symptoms from arimidex while i was on it...but since being off it....my body feels better now...7years later...then it did while i was on arimidex. don't give up.¬† hang in there.¬† remember you were given medicine and treatment to kill cancer...prevent relapse.¬† it works...but at times difficult to accept the SE.¬† also depends on what chemos you got, etc. hugs diana50

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2009 11:12AM diana50 wrote: TAC kicks cancer's butt.¬† i am one of the people who got TAC in a clinical trial in 2002. right after the trial was showing results...it pretty much became standard treatment for lots of positive nodes. even tho my report said 10/12 positive...my surgeon was pretty sure because of the spread and "total encasement" i had more.¬† from my experience...i really really believe in chemo and TAC has certainly done the job for many of us .¬† it sounds like you got a lot of information on your oncology visit.¬† give yourself some time to wrap your head around this.....one day at a time and try to not get tooo far ahead of yourself.¬† all of us are here for you; keep posting . this is one of the hardest times...right after being diagnosed and beginning to understand what is going on.¬† hang in there and know we are here for you. gentle hugs diana50

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2009 07:08AM - edited Nov 29, 2009 07:09AM by diana50 Merry we are here for you. just ask all the qustions you want; many many women post here.¬† as kerry said; take it one step at a time.¬† try to not get too far ahead of yourself; surgery is rough..your body has to heal...and then you begin the other treatments.¬† look at each stage as Treatment...getting rid of the cancer cells...clearing your body...and then the healing.¬† the treatment for stage 3 is very very good; lots of options and by the time you finish you will have had the "full monty"¬† which is a good thing.¬† try to rest...very important...pace yourself.¬† remember; you are alive right now....and in treatment. i joined a support group at my place of treatment and met some women who are still my breast buddies to this day. it was helpful to talk with folks who had been in treatment or were going through what i was going through. ¬†i will be hitting the 8 year mark in feb....doing well at this end.¬† this is not an easy trip; but necessary to go through all the stuff they put us through.¬† be sure you like your doctors..and medical team; as they will be with you a long time. ask questiosn when you don't understand something...write to us on this forum and lots of women will answer your questions. hang in and gentle hugs diana50
Posts.Title: Help. So scared! merryheart AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2010 02:28AM diana50 wrote: hi jenn keep coming here and venting...expressing your feelings is just so important.¬† aftercare...and after the trauma of Dx...treatment....etc....it is just all so hard.¬†i remember keeping a positive outlook during all the "stuff" we do....and then when finished....i was really stressed.¬† it is kinda like falling into a hole....and wondering when you will hit the bottom.¬† there is no clear cut way to feel during all of this....from 1 year out...to 3 years out...to 5....to 8...to 10.¬† i think we "adjust" and continue to live our lives the best we can. ¬†be kind to yourself.¬† just be where you are....you are doing great.¬† diana50

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2015 03:41PM diana50 wrote: I started with rads to T4 and letrozole. Letrozole worked almost 2 years but TM elevating but clear Pet/Ct scans. Kidneys involved and small lesion on liver. Taxol for 10 months. Lowered TM for 8 months but TM started back up. Kidneys improved greatly but liver lesion grew Ixempra 5 months. Total bust. Progression. Gemzar one week on and one week off. Dropped TM 550 points and just had them done this week. Kidney function normal. Liver feels better. I believe gemzar is working. Scan in January. I think if I have good results either will do maintenance on gemzar or switch to Ibrance with either letrozole or faslodex. Foundation one identified Ibrance as option for me. That's all I got. Right now my issues are SE from chemo. Not from cancer. Best Diana

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2012 12:18PM diana50 wrote: hi dlm you are only 6 months out from initial diagnosis and still in treatment.¬†crying in the shower sounds like a release of many pent up emotions; i remember not feeling much when i was initially diagnosed and was very strong during treatment.¬† having cancer is so much to wrap your head around; i found it took me awhile to really understand what i was going through and had to deal with for a long while* i believe that crying is really good for you.¬† there are so many levels of dealing with breast cancer; initial diagnosis...treatment...the physical changes....(of which you will heal and recover from but it takes a long time) ..the emotional/psychological challenges...the ongoing follow up treatment and fears around relapse...etc... yeah, crying is a good thing dlm.¬† you do want to feel your feelings when they show up* the boards are the best place to come for understand and cyber hugs.¬† we get it.¬† there are so many of us at different stages ...newbies...2-3 year peeps out....5 years....8...and 10 years and more.¬† i just really believe you have to take it one day at a time; be where you are....feel what you feel....do your treatment.....and don't give up even on the bad days. hugs diana

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2014 05:59AM diana50 wrote: spring watch Just finished my first tx of taxol. After the steroid wore off I was fatigued for two and half days. This chemo can lower blood pressure , pulse, red cells and white. I was a walking zombie starting day 2-3-not so bad 4 day. ¬†But I have only had 1 tx so far. ¬† My MO checks vitamin B , iron and magnesium. ¬†If your pulse is low and blood pressure too you will feel weak and fatigue. Drink a lot of water to bring up blood pressure. ¬† Hope you feel better¬†

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 02:01AM diana50 wrote: My experience with arimidex was that i had a lot of pain; my body ached most of the time. i stayed on it because i wasn't thinking that switching to femara might be a good idea. my friend was on arimidex...had the same kind of pain...and switched to femara and has done much much better on the femara. way less pain. it seems that femara is more tolerable then the arimidex from what i have read on the boards..and heard from other women. remember, these AI's stop the production of estrogen; which really does have a big influence on your body. also, you are only a year out....all that chemo and rads really plays havoc on our body...and i think it takes awhile to heal. since i have been off the arimidex after 5 and half years...my body feels better then it has since being diagnosed. hope you feel better....HUGS. hang in there

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 10:15PM diana50 wrote: welcome home snowflake glad you are feeling a little better; i had an embolism and was on coumadin for 6months until the embolism resolved.¬† it is good to start with chemo; it will get in there and take out the cancer cells immediately**** i started chemo first (after surgery) and i was glad to get started on it when i did.¬† i believe in chemo and am still no evidence of cancer (NED) after 7 years.¬† it is hard where you are now; just getting diagnosed, having the embolisms...and moving into the treatment stage.¬† however, i felt like i was in more control when i started to get my infusions of chemo and felt like i was making progress in battling this stupid disease.¬† make relationships with the chemo nurses; ask questions...let them know how you are feeling, etc.¬† you may want to check into support groups; at my cancer center they have groups for "us"¬† and also groups for partners and significant others..¬† when i was diagnosed i googled support groups, etc in my area and got involved so i didn't feel so alone.¬† and of course, you have all of here at breastcancer.org. take care warrior **** one day at a time; prayers and hugs diana50
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - what should we look for in a doctor? Snowflake70 LindaYO

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2011 03:08PM diana50 wrote: having cancer is a personal nighmare.¬† however, it does affect all the people who love you.¬† my experience of this is that each patient has to make their own decisions....find their own way.¬† beliefs can make you choose one treatment over another.¬† i also believe, that people can change their minds about what they decide to so.¬† the initial diagnosis can totally rock your world and can take a person into various decisions....some of which may change over a course of a few months. ¬†i really believe, unless you have been dx with cancer; it is hard to imagine what you would do in the reality of cancer. ¬†for me, i really believe in current medical treatments; surgery is the most important part as it reduces the tumor burden on the body.¬† chemo, rads and hormone treatment clean up the rest of the bad cells.¬† stage III patients do get aggressive treatment becaiuse of the stage of the disease.¬† i am 9 years out and doing well.¬† i really believe in the treatment i got and why i am doing so well. ¬†the issue is that it is an individual decision.¬† people have to do what they are comfortable with.¬† i am sorry¬†this is so hard. ¬†maybe the best you can do is just be there. sometimes, over a period of time...being there can make a difference.¬† hang in there diana

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 10:29AM diana50 wrote: hi karina the treatment for cancer is the bottom line' surgery, chemo, rads, hormone treatment....reconstruction.¬† just remember that what you are going through is going to "kick cancer's butt" trusting the treatment is really important; especially right now for you.¬† this is such a long process; after initial diagnosis....surgery...etc....and right now you proabably ARE having gray days.¬† these drugs really rock us physically and emotionally, much of how you are feeling IS related to how vunerable you are feeling because of the treatment...and fears about the future.¬† so, i am 9 years out.¬† i feel better then i have in 10 years.¬† however, i do remember my fears...how sick i felt at various times during treatment...(food tasted like cardboard..i would buy a lot of groceries and end up tossing them because my eyes were hungry but NOT my mouth or stomach)¬† come here often and post.¬† know one thing; right now, today...you are alive and living...stay in the moment and don't get into future...or "what if"¬† you can have bad days.....but don't stay there...and there will be good days ahead.¬† just keep on...keep on. i have a friend who today is celebrating 11 years out with very similar diagnosis as you.¬† HUGS

Posts.Content: diana50 wrote: Depression and stress related to breast cancer diagnosis and treatment is real.¬† Pain from treatment; surgery, chemo, rads, hormone stuff .etc is something we all go through.¬† i wanted to share my experience with antidepressants and what has really helped. I was on paxil for a number of years after my treatment, etc.¬† anxiety totally ran my life after the stage III diagnosis.¬† additionally, i was suffering from chronic shingles and pain from the arimidex. a friend of mine suggested cymbalta .¬† cymbalta is an antidepressant; it treats depression, anxiety and "nerve pain"¬† usually prescribed for diabetics because it helps with the neuropathy.¬† well, i switched from paxil to the cymbalta and i have to say that it really helped the nerve pain that i was experiencing from the shinges..and most likely left over from the taxotere.¬† just wanted to share this info.¬† the depressive symptoms seem WAY less as well. Not today cancer. Nope. Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2015 10:09AM - edited Jul 16, 2015 10:10AM by diana50 Yes I have trouble with my port at various times. It really sticks out for some reason. On my right side of chest and when I lift stuff or over use right arm slepping groceries etc my port will bother me. The cath runs under my right cavical and I can see it and feel it. Kinda creepy. But when I over use it I kinda massage the cath and it feels better. I am right handed and I think that adds to it. When I was getting two infusions weekly the port was helpful as it also got tender. I think keeping an eye on it is really important. They can always do a blood culture. They draw blood from port and then draw blood from arm and culture it. It is possible to have a silent infection around the port and if doesn't clear up show to your onc. Anyway. Hope you can get into your gardening

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2015 01:00PM diana50 wrote: My worst pain was from shingles on my neck and into my ear back in December and January. I was taking norco 7.2 and it kinda worked. With shingle nerve pain it helped but I was popping them like M&Ms. After the shingle pain subsided to tolerable level I cut way back on norco. I found a half norco in AM and the other half in afternoon allows me to exercise and do my stuff. My pain now is mostly feet (31 taxols and still getting it 3-1 weeks/off) and my bone met in spine will ache from time to time. I am very careful to not take too much pain medicine during my shingle thing my pain was a million. And I did get through that. Whew. I use pain meds so I can walk, exercise and do my stuff. I know I wouldn't be able to walk every day if I wasn't taking the half pain med @6 hours. However I am very careful about taking too much or too often üëçüëç

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 12:29PM diana50 wrote: hi mimiof4 i think it is kind of an individual healing process after chemo; you will feel better...slowly but surely....depends on what chemo you got...rounds...your health before you started chemo...complications if any...exercise...lots of stuff. i see you say you have always been a high energy person; but remember that the chemo affects red and white blood cells so even if you are high energy your body may not be until you heal from the wipeout from chemo.¬† after i finished my chemo i too had the rad appt; and i know they didn't start my rads until my white and red blood cells were up to par.( a few¬†weeks or so)¬† rads can also alter the red blood count and with me they checked it fairly regularly.¬† now that you have finished chemo; i recommend you drink water....rest....do a little walking..and slowly allow your body to heal. i am happy for you that you have finished chemo. good for you. remember that chemo is an accumulation effect...and my experience was that the last two chemos really knocked me out...i felt lethargic for awhile....¬† it isn't so much psychological as it is actually physical. so, hang in there...the chemo did its job.....all you have to do now is heal up from the onslaught of cancer killer. it also takes awhile to get used to post treatment...you almost have to "get to know" your body and psyche' again...because from my experience...things change after cancer on a few levels. ¬†hang in there. i am sure others will be around to offer their support too* diana50

Posts.Content: diana50 wrote: Have had a little hard time the last 8 weeks. Brain scan end of May identified 4 cm lesion in dura. Not in brain mater. No SE and caught me and oncologist off guard. The dx initially was brain met. Fast forward to today. Had a second opinion and opinion was B9 mennigoma. Has been there a long time to reach 4cm. No symptoms. Found on incidental scan in May. Totally rocked my safety. Thinking I can do liver mets; but the large lesion in my head another story. Second opinion was the lesion was B9 mennigoma. Not cAncer. No change from scan in May. Recommends monitoring lesion. Having spinal tap july 15. Only one doc believed it was B9. Moral of story. I believed the lesion was B9. Hx of brain lesions on maternal side and women with Hx if breast cAncer do have B9 brain lesions. Also being in age group is significant. You never know for sure. Will continue Lxempra for liver lesions but the head stuff has become less scarey. I hope I am not in denial but never believed I had cAncer in my brain. Just because something shows up doesn't mean its cAncer. Once and awhile there is good news. Not often but it is there. Always get a second opinion b/c we are lumped into a cAtagory with metastatic disease. Still fighting. Still have faith in God and healing. Only best to all. Yep üëç Diana Not today cancer. Nope. Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 10:58PM diana50 wrote: i think our stage...our diagnosis...our pathology....is as indivdual as we are. no cancer is exactly the same....and each of us have our own life history...developmental stage...age...emotional/psychological strengths and weakness...health...history. there is no right or wrong way to feel. in my support group in which i participated for a year on a weekly basis during my treatment..there were all different stages...from DCIS to stage 4..with some of the members passing away.¬† i realized then that each of us struggles and each of us does our cancer in our own way even though we share "cancer diagonis" i think expressing how you feel and what you think is good. from my experience..of all of this...now 8 years out...my ideas have changed about a lot of things...from my feelings when diagnosed to where i am now.¬† cancer just is. that is all i know. how we deal with it is as indivudal as each of us are. that is what i think...and that is all i know. hugs

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 05:45AM diana50 wrote: wessa i am not reading any more books on surviving cancer....and i eat pretty much what i want .¬† i do try to get the veggies and fruits in; but i eat meat...onion rings...and ice cream.¬† the cycling i do is what i did before breast cancer; and i just love the cycling and never have given it up.¬† since i am retired and have more time; i am able to get longer rides in. oh yes, not a gin and tonic fan, but i do have my wine cocktails because i enjoy wine. i take my multivitamin, vit D, B complex and fish oil.¬† but once again, i was doing that before cancer. there is a point where...for me...i want to live my life without being so controlled by the cancer diagnosis.¬† we are both 9 years out.¬†i have pretty much resolved in my mind; that if the cancer comes back; it is just what it is.¬† i spent the first few years making myself crazy thinking¬† i could control if it comes back or not.¬† however, i do think that within reason; taking care of myself on some level is important.¬† maybe wisdom is living your life and enjoying a gin and tonic on a hot day* hugs diana

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2015 06:46PM diana50 wrote: Hi Nancy I feel good about my team; partly because my onc has been my onc for 12 years. Many of the chemo nurses were my nurses back in 2002. So there is consistency. The nurses are on the front line and where we get chemo the onc offices are right around the corner. So if there are questions on blood work or emergency etc the nurses can talk in person with onc. They have perimeters set for each patient on bloodwork: i.e. Like if patient is below perimeter on magnesium they get mag. Plus the cancer center is on main hospital campus. ER is right around the corner. I live in a small valley. There are only two hospitals treating cancer. There are options for other tx as UC system is close and City of Hope. Plus LA. Our doctors refer out if needed. plus Phoenix has Cancer Center of America. I feel grateful for the treatment I get. We need more options for clinical trials and they are talking with UC San Diego for options.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2016 09:55AM - edited Feb 16, 2016 09:56AM by diana50 thanks for this thread Mrs Devine Well this are my thoughts on statistics. When I was Dx with stage 3 in 2002 I was praying for 5 years before mets would show up. I thought for awhile I was going to be a goner. I waisted 2-3 years worrying about the cancer coming back. My surgeon even recommended keep the port " in case". After 3 years of "clean" I decided " if the cancer comes back I'll deal with it b/c I already have once" and was able to move on. Almost 11 years later mets. (2012)Now I'm 14 year cancer patient with mets liver, kidneys, bone. Doing actually pretty good. My goal is to hit 65. (Medicare) I'm turning 64 in June. Once I get to 65 I'll set another goal. I still have lots of options for treatment and remain upbeat. (Most of the time üòâ). No one knows how you will do. Keep plugging along. My thing is I try to avoid complications (infection, bad nutrition etc). I don't want stuff like kidney stents placed unless really necessary. I said no back in 2014 and wanted to give taxol a chance to work and it did. No stents yet. The book Being Mortal really changed how I think about this cancer business. Not today cancer. Nope. üòé Diana.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2014 04:09PM diana50 wrote: spicy since you weren't having problems with the port and now you are...i would ask for as port study.¬† the port study looks at the placement of the needlle access area and also the cath coming off into the vein.¬† the second port study made it clear i needed a new port. my surgeon said that my upper body (muscles and body structure) may be part of my problem.¬† i was also lifting weight and i think i caused the initial pull out of the cath.¬† on the second one; surgeon added an inch on the cath..and that seems to be the ticket.¬† my upper body had changed a lot in the last 10 years as i was an avid road bikler.¬† in 2002 i had no problems with my port (i wasn't cycling like was the last 10 years).¬† he said i could lift light weights which i am doing 3x a week¬† no prolems. at any rate; thses kinds of problems we don't need.¬† i am so happy to my port working; i got my 10 chemo today; and i was said to the chemo nurse..i am so glad my port is working.¬† good luck and best.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2013 02:55PM - edited Dec 7, 2013 02:56PM by diana50 i was diagnosed in feb 2002. small tumor but 10 fully encased lymph nodes. Tx was lumpectomy, nodes, TAC (which was a clinical trial back then) and rads. 6 years on arimidex. the first few years were rough', i was scared...anxious..and every little ache..i thought "cancer" took me a few years to get comfortable in my body after the aggressive treatment and also for me to wrap my emotions and head around having a "cancer diagnois" i didn't have scans but i did see my onc every 6 months for blood work and tumor markers. in august of 2012, ,my tumor marker doubled. i had always been below normal. onc did the test again and it was even higher. i had no pain anywhere except in my right hip. all other blood work great. onc scanned my hip' all i had was a tear in a muscle from too much cycling. she then ordered a PET/SCAN//./and there it was on my T4 vertebra. i had become metatastic. well, i petrifried scared....had to have biopsy...after biopsy found out my cancer was exactly same pathology was it was in 2002. i was never cured but just in remission for 10 and half years. i couldn't believe it. tx as been 25 rads to T4 vertebre, monthly zometa and letrozole. so, i had trouble wrapping my head around the stage4 dx. it took me about 6 months to really work through my feelings about the whole thing. but, i have. i feel so grateful for each day; narely think about stage 4 until i go to the cancer center monthly for my zometa or when i am having side effects. i don't think that i will necessarily die from cancer.i think about Boston...and realize that anything can happen at any time. i am not a pollyanna about my cancer; i am actually very realistic. but i was 49 years old when i was initially diagnosed and now i am 61. that is a lot of living; a lot of loving..and i am grateful. I eat good; but i don't do green drinks. i exercise every day'; walking right now. off the bike because i had surgery on my foot. i journal. i pray every day. i have been able to see my 5 year old nephew grow into a a 16 year old young man. time has been good to me. i only hang with people who love me and i love back. i avoid toxic people. oh, i drink white wine. i don't think of myself as a survivor...more of a warrior...but really, just a woman who got breast cancer, did the treatment...and continues to live life and make the adjustments that i have to make..around the cancer stuff but just also as i age/. aging is a good thing. that is all i got./ it is a rollar coaster ride some days....but take heart that there are all kinds of new trials and treatments. there are some patients who do really well. you can be one of those patients. i have a friend who is stage 3 who is 14 years out and doing great. i don't post much on the boards now, as i see many of my breast cancer peeps on facebook. but i wish each and every one of you all the best this Christmas and Holiday season. and always into 2014. that is all i got. diana 50

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2009 12:32PM diana50 wrote: dear cheryl i had these long locks...but after Dx i went and got a short cut.¬† after 14 days of first TAC, my hair started falling out.¬† so...got myself a baseball cap and went to Supercuts...lol..and had my head shaved.¬†and that was it.¬† actually, even after shaving...there was the tiny little hairs that also came out.¬† actually, i guess what makes the hair fall out is the hair foolicle gets irritated from the chemo...cause (sometimes) a prickling sensation...eventually, once i had my smooth bald head i was much comfortable. well, i have to tell you....(i am not sure many felt like i did)¬† BUT...i really liked being bald.¬† i think when you are going through all the treatments...it is nice to not have to think about HAIR> of course, i live in the desert ...and my treatment was in the summer...but i felt very cool with no hair.¬† also, i used to out and "tan" my bald head a little....so i wasn't so pastey. i never wore a wig; they felt funny to me....but i did on occassion wear pretty scarves..and baseball hats...and straw hats..since it was summer.¬† so, now....when i go and get my hair cut...the stylist knows i liked being bald 7 years ago....i now wear my hair very very short and sassy.....when it came in it was very cury....i still have waves in back and on sides.¬† i wore my baldness with pride that i was in treatment and fighting cancer.¬† i guess for me it symbolized what i was going through.¬† every one is different in how they feel and how they handle it.¬† any way you look at it....battling cancer is tough...some days easier then others tho** hang in there warrior** hugs diana50

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2010 09:23PM diana50 wrote: Patsy something that really helped me during chemo was to keep track a DAILY log of symptoms and feelings.¬† all the way through. doesn't have to be elaborate...just jot down physical and emotional symptoms.¬† i found during the cycles that the days were pretty predictable ......when i kept track...i knew which days were going to be hard days...and which days were going to be better so i could plan outings...etc.¬† also, i knew when i HAD to rest.¬† i rested every day during chemo; had a schedule..up at same time every day...shots...rest at 1 pm ....sometimes just to ponder...pray...cry...whatever...the time between 1-3 pm was MY time to deal with this disease. i still have my calendar....i look at it now and wonder how i did it but i did. you will too. always talk with nurses...let them know symptoms...etc. there are good meds for stuff. hugs diana

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2010 07:16PM diana50 wrote: Time. during treatment and for sure,...at least a year...two years...it takes awhile to begin to understand where your tender areas are. radiation pretty much injured my ribs and for at least a year and half i had issues...(4 broken ribs..not cancer..but from rads).¬† working out has always been a priority for me; i cycled during treatment and continue to cycle.. my body ached during arimidex.¬† i think as time goes on...and you begin to identify the areas where your aches and pains are...eventually they do get better..then that is part of the trust issue.¬† i trust that the aches and pains i have are a result of treatment..and of course "older age" and i guess i you learn to identify the parts of your body and get to know how they feel. i believe that i will KNOW if i have a tumor somewhere...like bone mets because i think it will feel different then the current pains. your question is so good. the follow up onc appts will help you too; blood work..etc. i used to document my aches and pains...over time to keep an idea on them...and to notice if there was anything new. that seemed to help me feel a little more in control. hang in there. finish treatment and give yourself some time to heal. even after 8 years..i still "check" my auxillary area for changes.¬† i think that is good monitering and nothing wrong with that. it is really is ok to be a little hperviligent around these issues.

( i see her every 6 months)¬† my experience of life is that you can never be prepared for "hard" events...whether divorce...accidents...cancer....and i guess life is just like that.¬† i think what has helped me the most is just plain ole acceptance of the unpredictability of life ...some days are good days..and some days are hard days.¬† all i know, i just want to keep going...enjoying...being grateful....and living while i am here on this earth.¬† that is all i know. Hugs ** you are all so awesome and stronger then you know* diana

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 01:02PM diana50 wrote: hi becs i have had two port studies; one in july and one in august.¬† the first port that was put in july, the cath came out of my vein.¬† i had the radiologist intervention team¬† "reposition the cath" and it worked like only once and then stopped working.¬† after the second study; it was determined the cath was too short and i really needed a new port and a different location.¬† so, i had the second port placement in august and now it is working correctly.¬† the surgeon added an inch on the cath and tunneled the cath under my collarbone into the vein there. i get weekly taxol and fuids; the port is supposed to work without complications.¬† the port study will give your doctor some good information.¬† i had my surgeon consult on it with the interventional radiologist and we all decided the best thing was to take out the bad one and put in a new one.¬† good luck.¬† it is a pain in the butt when stuff isn't working.¬† like we don't have anything else to do but deal with a broken port.¬† hang in there i hope they get you fixed up very fast with no problems.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2015 05:49PM - edited Nov 12, 2015 05:49PM by diana50 ocean My TM's popped last July 2012 to 850 from 300 and Pet scan confirmed. I was having kidney issues with cancer wrapped around kidneys. Started weekly taxol and the taxol cleared out the cancer and I avoided stents. Was stable on taxol but once again TM popped to 1385 in September. Scans showed progression in liver. Started gemzar October and after one cycle TM dropped 400. Too early for scans. TM can be accurate for people and then again not. Scans are gold standard but in my case TMs have been reliable. Rads and new treatment can bring your moms TM down if they are accurate for her. Ask about scan results. Best to you and your mom.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2015 01:14PM diana50 wrote: Terri At my cancer center they give all chemo patients follow up fluids either day after chemo or two days later. Back in 2002 when I was on chemo they didn't do that. I think the extra in fluids really helps right after chemo. Also we get iv magnesium if we are low on that. I needed the magnesium the more taxol a I did as time went on. Low magnesium will make you feel wiped out. So maybe ask about that level when you go in for blood work. Now I take magnesium supplements (Slow-Mag) daily. The extra fluids really helped as they want us to drink fluids after chemo and sometimes it's hard to get hydrated. The iv fluids helps in that department. Hope you feel better Diana

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 07:21PM diana50 wrote: my experience of this life (after 58 years) is that stuff happens.¬† if you live long enough...things are going to come your way that rock your boat.¬† it is all very traumatizing. being diagnosed with cancer is traumatizing...going through aggressive treatment is traumatizing.¬† but, there are other things that happen in life that are also very difficult.¬† i think that having a life threatening disease is the bottom line when it comes to trauma,¬† i also think..and have experienced...that you reach deep inside to work through this stuff to get to the otherside.¬† i liked what Celtic said; you just keep slugging the battles.¬† my experience is just that; you keep slugging away...getting back on the saddle ....otherwise...you just really don't have much at all if you give up.¬† life¬†is life.¬† each day is each day. that is really all we have.¬† when i am alive....all i want to do is enjoy my loved ones...my pleasures...and the moment.¬† that is really all we all have;' cancer or no cancer. hang in there. do one day at a time.¬† never give up.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2015 08:07PM diana50 wrote: Jennifer This is a topic I was so interested in when first Dx with mets in 2012. Bone met. Rads and letrozole. I kept thinking why not blast this cancer out ? As time passed and I had another biopsy in 2014 my pathology changed significantly. Cancer becoming more aggressive. Then the chemo started; taxol, Lxempra and now in gemzar. ( gemzar is kicking my butt but also cancer ). I can't help but also wonder about aggressive vs starting with hormone; etc. what bothers me the most as as we go through varying chemos our bodies over time become weak. Blood counts down. Etc. I iften wonder if my onc would have started with aggressive tx if I would be in a different place then I am now. Any of us. I need to read more about this. I got TAC in 2002 and was in remission for almost 11 years. They kicked cancers booty in 2002. Now the goal is " to keep me stable" with mets in bones , liver and kidneys. üò±üò≥. 3 and almost 6 months with mets. Easy treatment to weekly chemo. Doesn't always make sense.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 10:17PM diana50 wrote: I like what Apple said; it is kind of like manners.¬† either you get it or not.¬† Interesting thread tho; when i was dx and in the treatment...people would say chemos isn't THAT bad is it?¬† or You WIll be FIne....blah blah blah....I had a few really good friends totally beside me...but many people i interacted with were really uneducated about breast cancer; stages, treatment for different stages, prognosis, choices during treatment and really unaware of many of the dynamics of having cancer.¬†(body breakdowns...everything we go through)¬†actually, prior to my own diagnosis i was pretty much one of those "stupid' people out there generalizing whatever information i had about cancer. Interesting now tho; after 7 years...when I tell people I am a 7 year BC survivor...they are actually more sensitive and supportive then ever.¬† Maybe in 7 years¬† from when I was diagnosed (2002) to 2009 so much more education about BC is out there; OR more people know more people diagnosed with it. Havng breast cancer..whether very early stage or late stage...is a very rough ride....from the moment you hear those words "You have breast cancer"¬† to each day you survive.¬† My experience tho....through my first couple of years...middle to 7 years has changed in how i feel and think about all of this.¬† I think now; trying to educate people about the disease (if they want to know) is where i am now.¬† and all i can educate them really ..is my own experiene and what i have learned about bc. ¬†These boards are great. I refer women (any men if they are interested) to read these boards and educate themselves .¬† sometimes people say stupids things.¬† i shrug my shoulders and can only know what i believe and what my truth is.¬† that has seemed to work . ¬†gentle hugs and prayers diana50

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 04:46PM diana50 wrote: hi everyone as i read your posts i remember clearly what a wreck i was post treatment....i was just waiting for a met to found during routine scans.....and then when they were clear....there was always a nagging thought..."well, maybe they missed something"¬† it really gets better down the road when you are able to begin to trust....and get to know...your new post treatment body.¬† i am at the point now where i don't want any scans...and pretty much rely on blood work and how i feel (except of course mammo and breast MRI for my very dense breasts...((thought the density would diminish with arimidex and old age......NOT )¬† lol¬† there was a shift in my thinking as time passed; i stopped assuming BC...and started to realize that i had good treatment...and i can begin to trust.¬†¬† i still think and know i COULD relapse but i am not always thinking about it.¬† it has less steam .¬† there is a lot of adjustment to learning about your post treatment body; and the damage from aggressive treatment....it takes awhile.¬† at the same time; i see my oncologist every 6 months...have blood work and if i am noticing anything like cough...pain...that doesn';t go away i bring it to her attention.¬† i have learned because of a few complications..(like 4 broken ribs and collapsed lung) it is not always cancer causing the problem.¬† i coniser myself an aggressive patient too; if i am really concerned..i will go into my onc and request her opinion on scan or whatever.¬† i would say the last few years....i am much less reactive...have gotten to understand my post treatment and aging body better...(lol) and have found some peace.¬† we each find our own way....and each of you are already doing that* hang in there hugs and peace diana50

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2014 09:28PM diana50 wrote: Great thread. I have been a cAncer patient since 2002. Mets in 2012. Interesting because my purpose has been my professional career. Not married. No kids. I do have cats Our social worker at my cAncer center a few months ago said to me " don't lose your purpose ". At the time I was like " what do you mean ". Well I get it now. There are so many losses with cAncer. You all know. But after thinking about this I decided a couple of things. I (we) are so limited with this cancer . There are so many losses which can pluck us out of life. I coached and was a family therapist for 35 years. Now at 62 with this disease I have found a new purpose. I give time to newbies diagnosed with cancer. My 12 years can help them. I support them. I am nice to people. Give time to people struggling with major issues. Maybe just being nice to another person is purpose. Maybe an elderly person who needs help at the grocery store. Supporting people at the cAncer center who R newly dx. Asking the chemo nurses how they Are. I smile at people I don't know. There are any people struggling. I believe in good things and I try to pass that along. I walk my neighbors dog because owner is crippled Being kind to others is purpose. It isn't always about " doing" as much as it is about being. Our purpose changes even if we don't have cAncer. As long as your heart beats; there is purpose. Our losses R profound. Being human being is priceless. You will be amazed how valuable you are to so many. I see it at the infusion center every day. A kind word and a smile is " purpose". I will always believe this. Keep on.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2014 02:21AM diana50 wrote: As an athlete ( basketball, running , road bike, plus coaching for 20 years) my thinking and emotional self seems to be competition, suffering, breaking through huge bumps; understanding winning and losing. Training. I actually look at cancer as my opponent. That seems to fuel my outlook and every day I am "training" to defeat my opponent. There have been some setbacks and very scary moments. But I have been " doing breast cancer" since 2002. Mets 2012.¬† I just got a new port yesterday. My one from July 14 broke. I have dodged kidney stents. Today is number 4 taxol. Cancer is wrapped around my ureters. My kidneys are swollen. It all sucks.¬† This is my life along with so many other aspects to me. I am not a survivor. Not a warrior. Journey ? ¬†I don't know and I don't care what I call it or what anyone else calls it. I just want quality , joy and grateful feelings to surround me. On a very bad day I am still grateful to be alive. At least now. And that is all I have. Today.¬†

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 04:17AM diana50 wrote: i think just getting used to your post treatment body is part of all of this.¬† i have a lot of aches that i didn't have before....and the first few years after treatment i was worried all the time about relapse. i found that the chemo, rads and arimidex caused a lot of "inflamation" in my body .and i had a hard time with that.¬†even tho i was cycling and working out..during pretty much the whole time...i was still dealing with arimidex Sx ...etc.¬† i think now...and after a few years...i could pretty much tell what was really related to inflamation ...aging...etc.¬† now, i know which body parts ache. lol¬† and aren't cancer....however...my onc and i both decided that IF i really sense something going on...over a period of time...scan it.. but, i also know that there are many people wout there who have mets and never knew it.¬† so, i guess that is where the follow up and blood work..and regular looks at breasts..or other problem areas come in.¬† ¬†diana50

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2016 02:37AM diana50 wrote: Hi Whitney My ibc came back also to peritoneal lining belly which was hard to see on scans until invaded my kidneys , ureters and my kidney function tanked. I started weekly taxol and it cleared it up but basically my belly was full of cancer. Into the liver too. They wanted kidney stents I said NO and luckily the chemo worked. Had fluid build up too. The good news is chemo (3 chemos ) has worked and currently stable. On weekly gemzar now. Fluids. Lots of hydration. I have water or gator aid going all the time. Soup. Prune juice every night for constipation. Fluid in belly can be drained. I drink protein drinks every day. Have her onc check her iron. I now take iron supplement and it has helped with red blood cells. Also magnesium. If she is low on magnesium she will be weak. They can give her IV mag but you can also use Slow Mag which doesn't cause any abdominal problems. The weakness rolls into being unable to function. Or eat. Banana shakes. Hopefully she can build herself up so she can get chemo b/c that is what might clear out some of the cancer. It's hard when you are weak and having SE and can't eat. Anything she can drink with nutrition go for it. Hope things get better. Diana

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2015 04:57PM - edited Jul 20, 2015 04:59PM by diana50 hi everyone. Trying tocatch up as been on a fork road b/c of 4cm lesion in dura. Had a brain MRI in July to see if changes from May to july. No change and they think b9 mennigoma. Last week spinal tsp and headache continues. üòñüòñüòñ should find out tomorrow if I can put head lesion to bed. And lock the door. üëÄüëÄ Ask your onc about Lxempra for chemo. I believe used when taxenes fail. There are three of us on it and there is a thread. This is my 2 nd chemo as taxol worked for 10 months then liver lesion 2.5 cm. and TMs elevated. I am currently getting # 4 lxempratoday. My onc preferred to use this rather then then Gemzar or navebine and keep those and other chemos for later. My Tx has been Femara , taxol 1 every week for 3 and one week off. And know Lxempra. It seems not a lot of peeps on here have gotten Lxempra. Will have scan in a few months. All blood work is good right now. Google and look at studies. It doesn't affect kidney function badly but can raise liver function tests and alkaline phosphate. I feel good about this chemo. 1x@3 weeks. The third week I feel pretty good. The weekly taxol kickef my butt. Time to get unhooked. üëçüëç Oh you get neulasta shot dsy after infusion of Lxempra. Protocol. Best to all Diana

Posts.Content: diana50 wrote: This has been on my mind for a long time. Decided to just put some thoughts out. Especially since major progression July 2012. Liver bones kidneys. Stable now. I live very close to San Bernardino terrorist attacks. Horrible. These people got up; brushed their teeth and had breakfast. Went to work. Shot dead. So, I was thinking " why do I believe I will die from MBC?" Around the same time out here in protected desert area ; two 75 year olds were out in their golf cart and were hit by a woman on drugs. Dead. I started to rethink this. My brothers died in accidents. (18 and 30). No cancer. No warning. Nothing. They died. Yes, I'm sick. Sone of us will lose our lives b/c of MBC. I hate this disease and hate saying goodbye to people on the boards. So many of us suffering and going through the pain of this disease. However, changing my thinking process a little at a time has helped me cope. If you are out and about (errands and living in life ) anything can happen. I choose to not focus on "dying of MBC" until I am in hospice and that's clearly the way it's going. It has helped me define my life right now and not get caught up in " I am going to die from MBC". I don't feel like a deer in the headlights. No one knows what will happen. I believe in God and I figure He has my back. Keep plugging along. And plug somemore. Live life and do your errands. As my onc would say " no one knows ". Till it is time. Not today cancer. Nope. Hugs. Diana Not today cancer. Nope. Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 07:25AM diana50 wrote: dear twinmom sending you support, hugs and peace. the initial diagnosis and finding out you have cancer...is a total whirlwind of emotions...anger, fear; it feels like you life has totally been turned upside down....and yes, it has.¬† HOWEVER.....you will be working with professionals who treat cancer for a living...this is all they do....even tho this is your first exposure to having this disease.¬† as a 7 year survivor; i remember exactly the first few days..and weeks..and months after being diagnosed. you think you will never get through this....how can it REALLY be happening...and how to handle all of it.¬† well, you have found this site....people will help you here.¬† i suggest to take one day at a time; the hardest but most important thing you can do...is try and get your head and emtions around this and it take time.¬† ask questions....if necessary get other opinions,,,educate yourself...Dr Susan Love's Breast Book is good...there are other books out there... from my experience.....after kinda getting a handle on the diagnosis...talking to doctors..joining a support group..accepting that i DID have breast cancer....i was ready to fight..Fists UP. treatment is really important; correct diagnosis sets the stage for your treatment.¬† there are all kinds of treatments out there now; back in 2002 when i was diagnosed i was in a clincial trial; now that chemo is standard treatment.¬† after fear...shock....tears...anger...acceptance and treatment. sending you best wishes.¬† hang in there and ask for help when you need it. prayers diana50

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 03:16PM diana50 wrote: i will be hitting the 10 year mark in feb NED.¬† i talked with my oncologist about this my last appt.¬† i was concerned because my estrogen level was 30.¬† she said she would not put me on another AI because of the damage to bones....body...etc.¬† (i had done almost 6 years on arimidex)¬† anyway, i said to her..."so, the hypothesis is that the treatment worked....and she said yes"¬† i also had many fully encased lymph nodes...my surgeon said he was sure there were more then he actually got) but so far i am doing well.¬† i think there is a point where you do need to trust the treatment and hope and pray for the best.¬† stage III get very aggressive treatment and for me, i really believe in what i got and it was also time to stop.¬† i exercise a lot; cycle every day and walk 45 minutes a day.¬†i eat good and take a few vitamins.¬† i also have a friend who is starting her 12 th year NED with similar diagnosis but very larget tumor.¬† it is kinda a crap shoot; why some people end up with more cancer...and some do not.¬† who knows.¬† but again, at some point...for me, i was done with treatment and AIs¬† i think strenuous exercise is the key and eating good. oh, i pray a lot and tell God how grateful i am for my life and peeps.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 05:20PM diana50 wrote: dear cheryl sending yoy hugs....healing thoughts.....give youself some time to wrap your head and emtions around the dx and upcoming treatment,.¬† i remember "i wanted to die" i was so scared and ovewhelmed...and then i thought..."oh right..ihave cancer"¬† kinda lightened me up in my fear.¬† i didn't think i could handle all the stuff that was ahead of me.....but,..with me slowing down, gathering informations...talking to doctors..(i have great docs...really important) joining a support group....getting my warrior plan going...and taking one day at a time...i found that having cancer was doable...and i could do it.¬† i have to tell you, something that helped me...was i remember clearly...a few days after getting the news...etc.¬† i said to my self¬† " i can do this...i can fight and i will"¬† some days easier then others.;...some days joyful....some days full of dispair...some days¬† were kinda regular days.¬† rest is really important; i rested everyday in the afternoon; i used the time to think, pray, sleep...and i also used a small recorder to talk about my feelings...etc.¬† it was like journaling but easier .¬† YOU ARE NOT ALONE>¬† we are all in your back pocket... i am 7 years out . my friend with large tumor and lots of nodes...same stage is coming up on her 10 years out.¬† treatments are the best they have ever had now in the 2009. my chemo was a clinical trial and now it is standard.¬† (TAC)¬† have your bad days..have a pity party..don't stay there.¬† you can do this . use the boards...talk to us. we are here. diana50

Posts.Content: diana50 wrote: Hi people Got my results from Foundation One. Kinda interesting. Only 2 genetic mutations came up. 1. TP53. Nothing available for Tx except clinical trials 1. I'd rather do chemos I haven't done yet. Interesting this is the P53 on pathology reports. In 2002 (initial dx) was not even an issue. Now with mets has changed to make my cancer very aggressive. Boo 2. Good news. Identified FGFR2 gene which supposedly will respond to pazopanib which is Ibrance. Going to continue lxempra for a couple of infusions then most likely switch to Ibrance and Femara. Will be interesting to see how it all plays out. My onc is very good about not rushing into changing tx too fast and seeing how things play out. Blood work is good right now so not in danger. TMs are 974. Which are high. However, I feel better then I have in a year. I work at taking it a day at a time and also how my body feels and if liver and kidneys are working I'm good. It's simple. I can pee and liver is working. üëç Maybe in our lifetime there will be a cure. I pray to be true. Diana Not today cancer. Nope. Dx 2/26/2002, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 10/12 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 3/4/2002 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary Chemotherapy 4/3/2002 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 8/6/2002 Hormonal Therapy 8/10/2002 Arimidex (anastrozole) Dx 8/30/2012, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Radiation Therapy 10/2/2012 Bone Chemotherapy 7/8/2014 Taxol (paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 5/6/2015 Ixempra (ixabepilone) Chemotherapy 10/5/2015 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Hormonal Therapy 4/12/2016 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 11:03AM diana50 wrote: my surgeon told me that he has known a lot of oncologists and each one of them has a different way of practicing medicine.¬† he said,"oncologists deal with the sickest of patients" "life threatening disease" and they each have their own way of deaing with that.¬†so, in the doctor world; oncologists are really involved in treatment and trying to kill cancer.¬† i have had three oncologists;¬† my first oncologist was killed in an accident one month after i started chemo; my second oncologist got sick and had to leave her practice.¬† the oncologist i have now is very much business....not really emotional...but excellent and very very thorough in my follow up .¬† she doesn't panic (even when i do) but is very reasonable in my concerns.¬† i feel I can go and see her anytime i have a question and she will be glad to see me and follow-up my concerns.¬† i have confidence inher and i trust her; even if there is no "fluff" during the appointments.¬† she does have warm and fuzzy nurses in her office which make the visits work for me.¬† i have no doubt that if i relapse my oncologist will be by my side fighting for me. diana50

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2015 10:44AM diana50 wrote: Nancy This is a great topic. For me, as for all of us , is leaving behind our loved ones. I don't have a spouse or children, but I have a lot of people who love me. My sister has been my biggest concern. Our two brothers were killed in 1974 and 1975. It's just been the two of us since then. Our parents are gone. Our family of origin very small. Have had conversations with sister and she gets it and reassures me she will be ok and will stay in life. I have two cats; have made plans for them. I have been a person who is very independent and professionally active. Traveled to Eastern Europe doing humanitarian work in children's homes. Huge athlete. This cancer has tweaked that and I struggle daily with SE and at times feeling very incapacitated. I hate that part. I make adjustments and continue to find joy each day with the things I "can" do. Once that is gone I'm done. But every day I wake up and say " not today cancer" and get on with what I "can" do. Makes me happy. And I enjoy the competition with cancer. I dig in and fight. For all of us. Better days ahead. Hugs

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 05:15PM diana50 wrote: All i can talk about is my own experience.¬† ¬†i am 10 years out.¬† this is all an individual process......it has to do with lots of things'; support, your doctor...friends...family....time...scares along the way, treatment.¬† i think the hardest part for me was initial diagnosis; i was totally shocked and this threw me into a fear i had not experienced in my life.¬† i think that fear is what kept me on the edge for many years; always worrying about more cancer showing up.¬† the unknowns in life are what rock our world.¬† there are so many things in life we do; get married; have kids....change jobs...we are not thinking about divorce when we get married.¬† however; 2 out of 4 marriages end in divorce.¬† we have our kids without thinking about "what could happen to them" until something does.¬† we still get married and we still have kids.¬† we still change jobs with the unknown in front of us.¬† the difference with cancer.....for us....is that it COULD¬†eventually kill us.¬† if it comes back.¬† so, we are on the edge.....and some days it is just so hard. ¬†well. i really believe now, after these years of doing this cancer thing; that for me; you have to just practice and practice being in the day.¬† the moment.¬† who knows what is down the line; but what is down the line may or not make a difference in your cancer outcome.¬† what finally really helped me; was acknowledging the truth, that i am a cancer survivor...that so far so good.....and i know if cancer shows up again...i will do what i need to do to deal with it.¬† there is comfort along this thinking; as i try to acknowledge the cancer but at the same time...find a balance in accepting but also not getting too far ahead of myself.¬† we are dealing with our life.¬† it is not a divorce, a new job...or our kids.¬† you have already shown your strength by doing the treatment.¬† you are strong.¬† you are alive.¬† today is just one day.¬† tomorrow is another day.¬† you will and can deal with what comes down the pipe.¬† hope this helps. hang in there.¬† keep on.¬†don't give up.¬† time is your friend not your enemy. diana

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2011 05:01PM diana50 wrote: jen as you¬†survive; others will not.¬† the pathology of the tumor is part of this.¬† so, i am 9 years out but i have buried some friends with breast cancer and other kinds of cancer.¬† you have found yourself in with a group of people who have cancer; some make it and some do not.¬†a good friend of mine died at age 33 with aggressive triple neg breast cancer.¬† she left behind a 10 year old and a 3 year old.¬† it all depends on age, diagnosis, pathology... there are no answers; no way to make sense of it.¬† i am so sorry you have lost someone so special to you.¬† she did the fight.¬† she did what she could do. that is what we do.¬† i was thinking the other day as i was cycling; that life is just soo fleeting.¬† we do what we can.¬† we love, we have our families and we do the best we can.¬† we try to beat cancer.¬† we do the treatment...we take the drugs...we exercise.¬† we eat good.¬† the truth is about this disease is that there is no "for sure" answers to any of it.¬† so, i guess all we can do; is grieve our friends...love our family and friends and hope for the best.¬† i think having cancer makes you "grow up" very fast and when you least expect it.¬† hang in here.¬† there are still good things out in this life. i am so sorry your your loss.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 11:39AM diana50 wrote: i think post treatment is another one of those hurdles we have to work past.¬† during treatment and after initial diagnosis i was just trying to "fight" and get through all of it.¬† after treatment....growing yoiur hair back...taking stock in all the physical changes....and emotional changes.¬† then, the 3 month..or 6 month follow up oncology appts....and trying to find a new "normal" .¬† i think diana63 hit it on the head; trying to find out who we are after the first couple of years after treatment and diagnosis is part of the journey.¬† it takes a LONG time for our bodies to heal; taking armidex for 5 and half years also did a number on my body.¬† they say that the side effects of treatment lasts a long time; ie., fatigue, aches and pains...it is a constant reminder of what we have gone through.¬† i also think recovering is dependent on age and general health prior to initial diagnosis. acceptance, healing and recovery.¬† my experience was that i struggled with the acceptance of the changes in my body...and healing was slow.¬†staying in the "here and now" has helped me enjoy life more.¬† i know i COULD relapse...but i figure i will deal with IF and WHEN that happens.¬† i could get hit on my bike (especially the way the snowbirds drive in the desert in the winter...lol) but i try to live with gusto and deal with it.¬† not always easy....but necessary. hang in there diana50

Avoid regular mag b/c it is rough on stomach and intestines. If you are low on magnesium you will feel more aches and fatigue. Magnesium regulates muscles (heart) and blood pressure. I take 2 Ô∏èslow mag in AM and 2 night. I have had to get IV mag when my levels drop to 1.5. Good luck to those having scans. Happy for everyone responding to treatment. I pray for all of us that our oncs can find medicine that works on these liver invaders. I am on holding pattern. Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2014 04:41PM diana50 wrote: I get a Pet/CT scan. So I get the glucose tracer and drink the contrast. My last scan July 3 showed progression. Interesting though a new liver spot (1.8cm) was not shown on Pet/Ct scan but radiologist could see it on the CT portion. No metabolic rate. Cancer can hide. I am always interested in the SUV rate on Pet portion. The higher the value the more aggressive. ( from what I have read). My initial spinal tumor was 4. 6 SUV and the highest on July 3 scan was 2.8 in my belly. Go figure. The recent Pet/ct scan results changed my tx from letrozole to taxol. I had had clear scans for a year and half but with rising TM s. Finally cancer showed up on July 3 scan. And one of the spots on liver 1.8 cm only showed on the CT portion of the Pet/ CT scan. Kinda scarey I think. We rely on scans to see progression. They need to work is all I have to say about it. Best to you. Hang in.¬† Diana¬†

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 03:10AM diana50 wrote: i agree with annaanne; i had false positives on breast MRI's (one recommending biopsy) and that stuff really drove me crazy.¬† when i finished treatment i had regular scheduled appts with oncologist every 3 months.¬† those included blood work, ct scans; also a mammo once a year and a breast MRI once a year. (6 months mammo and 6 months MRI)¬† i had big problems with my treated breast for some reason; much swelling, fluid on my pec muscle..eventually 4 broken ribs under by treated breast from rads.¬† (no cancer)¬† it is pretty much healed up.¬† i finished treatment 7 years ago.¬† in the last few years; i see the oncologist every 6 months for blood work and only the mammo and breast MRI.¬† i have a totally different view of follow up now:¬† i see the doc for the blood work and mammo/MRI but now i really believe that if my cancer returns it will show itself and then i can deal with it then. i really, at this point, don't even want the breast MRI but i am one of those "dense breasts" gals. the "two week" plan is a good one i think.¬† if symptoms are there for 2 weeks; get it checked out. when the radiologsit recommended biopsy on an area seen on my breast MRI...i talked with my oncologist and we decided NO.¬† as i said; if it is cancer it will show itself. i think getting comfortable¬† with post-treatment is a really personal thing. i think listening to others, reading recommendations and talking to your oncologist helps a lot.¬† however, i have to say; when i look back when i had just finished treatment; i was so anxious about relaspe i wanted every test in the book*** lol¬† time makes all the differences in the world. trust yourself; trust your doc....take one day at a time.¬† my oncologist is great.¬† you will find a comfortable place with post-treatment ; all a part of the journey . diana50

Posts.Content: May 22, 2015 09:59AM diana50 wrote: HLB You are Not unreasonable. We are fighting for our life. When I go to see my onc I have a piece of paper with notes, tx options and questions. She expects that from me. Much is stuff I have learned on this site. She has been my onc for 13 years. Most onc expect patients to get a second opinion. Always an option. I think the best time to challenge and research is when you are well enough to do it. Once you are really sick it gets harder. Side note. I had my T4 radiated when first dx with mets. 24 rads and it totally took out the cAncer. It was eating its way to my spinal cord. The area is clean now and no complications from the rads to spine. Like I said. You are fighting for your life. We are just patients to our docs. Do what your gut is telling you and what you can do without too much stress. Hang in there. We are all here for you. Diana

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 05:55PM diana50 wrote: varying stages of breast cancer include spread to lymph nodes from tumor found in the breast. for example; i had a small tumor in my breast but spread to 10 lymph nodes.¬† HOWEVER,,,there are women who have experienced docs not finding a tumor in the breast....but cancer in the lymph nodes.¬† as i said; if you are high risk; and if your doctor knows this....breast MRI can get a better picture of dense breasts..and also can see lymph nodes.¬† i am 57 and still have dense breasts....even after all this cancer treatment...etc.¬† i would follow up....so you don't have to worry so much. it is common for doctors to "monitor" lumps....over a period of time.¬† i had something in my lung which they "watched". cancer grows....things that are beign don't change or grow. that is one way they 'watch ' it.¬† hang in there.¬† there is a lot of good information on these boards...and good to ask questions. those of us who are dealing with breast cancer have pretty good info...but we aren't doctors....so always check with your doc.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2010 06:25PM - edited Jan 7, 2010 06:25PM by diana50 i didn't work for 10 months while i was on¬†chemo and rads. my work involved very close contact with little kids...and i needed to be consistent and "there" every day for the work i was doing; so i went on disability.¬†i was also concerned about "chemo brain" because in the mental health field i¬†needed to be really available and while on treatment i was dealing with side effects..etc.¬†first time i had been off work for 28 years. wow.¬† what i did was really concentrate on MY needs. i put myself on a schedule; so i would get up every day...(not sleep in).., eat some cardboard..lol..i mean breakfast...and then i would do my excercise.¬† if i felt good; i would have a longer work out..if not i would cycle around the block. i usually had some kind of doc or blood work appt to do in the mornings.¬† afternoons; i rested. i took quiet time to read, pray...journal , cuddle with cats...or sleep if i needed to.¬† it was very important for me at that time to rest and have some time to myself going through the treatments. in the evening i would cook dinner...cardboard..lol...watch the news...tv and go to bed.¬† on good days; i would go out for lunch with friends.¬† i also attended breast cancer support group which i really enjoyed. having the time from work was good for me.¬† something i had not had in my life prior to diagnosis. i like it; i allowed myself to enjoy it.¬† it helped me realize that i liked doing other things like gardening...relaxing...reading and being with friends.¬† in 10 months i was ready to return to work and did so with enthusiasm. take care of yourself. it is ok to not be working. diana50

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2009 05:16PM - edited Dec 25, 2009 05:18PM by diana50 This is such a great question.¬† My experience is this:¬† i had 3 month appts with my oncologist where she did blood work and tumor markers.¬† she also did chest CT/belly CT once a year.i think partly because of my anxiety. hah¬† i also believe that if relapse is caught early..and it is "small" i would have a better chance to manage it(or get rid of it)¬†then if it is totally out of control.¬† another issue was brought to my attention by my surgeon. he talked about the farther you are out from chemo...the better especially if you need more chemo.¬† it seemed liked it would be more effective..the farther out you were...and you want to use the "big guns" if you relapse...he said,,"you might not want to use "big guns" on a small tumor...rather..look at other options..like hormone...or rads.¬† anyway,¬† that kinda made sense to me at the time.¬† after two years out; i only had mammo and breast MRI (every 6 months) and only an xray or scan if i had issues. i did have 4 broken ribs (from rads...) which caused a lot of craziness because they had to rule out mets....but i was clear. so, pretty much starting from 3 years-4 all i have had is blood work and breast scans.¬† instead of a breast mri that would be coming up; my doc ordered an ultrasound of my breasts..and 6 months later i will have mammo. i think our follow up is related to our own personal issues..side effects...pains..etc.¬† i am really comfortable now to see the oncologist every 6 months for blood work and no scans.¬† my doc also told me that the stuff they inject you with ..over a period of time..and lots of scans..is bad for your kidneys.¬† additionally, i think they just came out with the radiation from CT scans is not good for us.¬† the only time i have a PET is when they think there could be a relapse...(like my broken ribs) otherwise no.¬† i had bone scan also because of the broken ribs.¬† for me, the 2 week pain problem is when i would call and go and see my doc.¬† otherwise; i pretty much just do the¬†6 month appts.¬† if i relapse..i will deal with it then...and look at my options.¬† there is local reoccurance..or a new cancer in other breast..etc...and then there are mets.¬† being aware of your body..after treatment is also an adjustment. it is all hard. and i have found myself changing over the years in how i look at it and how i deal with it.¬† sorry so long winded here.¬†hope something here has helped a little. i think there is a balance that can be found . diana50

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2015 02:22AM - edited Jan 11, 2015 02:23AM by diana50 You are not stupid. This is a real shocker getting this information. It takes some time to wrap your emotions and head around it. The Pet scan is a good thing as the information will give you and oncologist opportunity for treatment plan. The Pet will let your onc if rads, chemo or oral or other stuff will help. Just remember. Lots of stuff available. Once you meet people here you will know what a strong group we are. Even on the hard days. A biopsy of the cAncer is important if they can get to it. Gives pathology and if things have changed in the last years. Also helps with treatment options. Always be thinking treatment options because there are many for us. I was initially dx in 2002 with mets in 2012. Doing well at the moment. Focus in on your life and how valuable you are to your people. Allow time to let the dx settle in but be proactive in your care. You are not alone even though you may feel like that right now this is a loving, supportive And knowledgeable community üëçüëç Keep on

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2010 01:11PM diana50 wrote: hi lemongrove you have a found a great place to talk, vent, ask questions and read about other's experiences/ the first couple of months after diagnosis....gathering all the information...talking with doctors...surgery...treatment choices...BILLS....are all very overwhelming. this is very scarey and i still remember exactly how i felt when i foung out that i had breast cancer. the good news is there are great treatments to help you fight this disease. the hard news it that it is a process...from beginning and on and on. everyone is different in how they did this; some people like to read all they can and some people want to just leave it to the doctors.¬† you are living...breathing...and alive right now. try to not get into the "what if"...that is not exactly helpful. once your docs gather all the information you will have a plan of attack. one day at a time. i was 49 when i was diagnosed. now i am 57 and looking forward to my 8th year out with no relapse. we do the Full Monty when it comes to treatment....and for me...i really believe in aggressive treatment. there will be bumps when you don't think you can move.....and some days not so bad. rest as much as you can. take care of yourself. there are a lot of tips that all of us can offer. just ask. Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2015 12:04PM - edited Jul 9, 2015 12:05PM by diana50 I think "feeling sick" is all relative to how many years we have been in Tx and often times side effects from Tx. Plus age and number of years we have been in Tx. I was feeling very sick a year ago when my kidneys were failing from waste build up in my body. Actually felt better when taxol worked and kidneys started working again. It all depends on where cAncer sets up shop in our body. Liver, kidneys, lungs, brain and bones. When Dx with spinal met in 2012 I was shocked as I was cycling and feeling great. But from the point it moved into kidneys I felt very sick. Now I feel pretty good except Lxempra side effects and neutopathy from taxol. Plus I am 63. üëÄüëÄüëÄ. When tumor burden is lessened in body with tx I think potential for feeling better is increased. Best to all. Hang Ineven on hArd days. Diana

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 11:51PM diana50 wrote: i have been doing tumor markers for 10 years.¬† for me; i think they are important.¬† my markers have changed in the last year and half; going up from the teens.¬† the highest is 34 but the last year has been elevating.¬† my onc (who i saw this week) looks at them as just another way to watch me.¬† she is doing blood work again in 4 months and an appt follows.¬† i don't freak out about the markers but i like to see what is going on inside me and the changes that occur.¬† i think that if there are changes in blood work; over a period of time, it MAY be something to look at.¬† all the other blood work is good; but the protein for breast cancer may be something to look at.¬† some people don;t do them; some people do.,¬† and for some people they aren't helpful at all.¬† i do blood work every 6 months.¬† that works for me.¬† i feel great.¬† no symptoms of anything.¬† but, in the back of my mind; i also realize that cancer is sneaky.¬† that is why i do the markers and why my onc seems ok with doing them.¬† i don't do scans unless really really necessary.¬† but if my markers really rise and i get into NOT NORMAL range; i will have a PET scan.¬† that way, i feel like i am taking care of business. lol¬†

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2009 07:36PM diana50 wrote: hi karen feeling terrified and overwhelmed with the whole thing is something i can relate too; and i think pretty much everyone i know who has been dx with breast cancer.¬† everything moved so fast; once i became a cancer patient....scans...surgery..chemo...rads....arimidex...shots up the butt...lol¬† BUT....here it is 7 years later i am alive, doing well...enjoying my current time here in this life.¬† i had to wrap my head around the diagnosis ...it took me a little while...and to adjust to all the stuff we have to do.¬† but, after i started reading....joined a support group...and talked with people...i settled into the "treatment" part and took one day....at a time...i did a lot of journaling so i could keep track of my symptoms during the chemo cycles which helped me predtict the next cycle.¬† i made friends in group; i made relationships with the doctors and nurses...i rested A LOT which i think really helped me heal on a daily basis...drank A LOT of water and found foods that my body craved...which i never like before...(like being pregnant_) lol¬† ask a lot of questions... everyone does cancer a little differently; my experience is that we find our way through the turns, corners...and straight a ways are a little easier.¬† ¬†we are here for you. ask questions..private message...everyone here wants to help newbies..people in treatment..people having a hard time... ¬†hugs...best wishes....prayers... diana
